lines.text: Enter AMIENS, JAQUES, and others

lines.speaker: amiens
lines.text: Under the greenwood tree Who loves to lie with me, And turn his merry note Unto the sweet bird's throat, Come hither, come hither, come hither: Here shall he see No enemy But winter and rough weather.

lines.speaker: jaques
lines.text: More, more, I prithee, more.

lines.speaker: amiens
lines.text: It will make you melancholy, Monsieur Jaques.

lines.speaker: jaques
lines.text: I thank it. More, I prithee, more. I can suck melancholy out of a song, as a weasel sucks eggs. More, I prithee, more.

lines.speaker: amiens
lines.text: My voice is ragged: I know I cannot please you.

lines.speaker: jaques
lines.text: I do not desire you to please me; I do desire you to sing. Come, more; another stanzo: call you 'em stanzos?

lines.speaker: amiens
lines.text: What you will, Monsieur Jaques.

lines.speaker: jaques
lines.text: Nay, I care not for their names; they owe me nothing. Will you sing?

lines.speaker: amiens
lines.text: More at your request than to please myself.

lines.speaker: jaques
lines.text: Well then, if ever I thank any man, I'll thank you; but that they call compliment is like the encounter of two dog-apes, and when a man thanks me heartily, methinks I have given him a penny and he renders me the beggarly thanks. Come, sing; and you that will not, hold your tongues.

lines.speaker: amiens
lines.text: Well, I'll end the song. Sirs, cover the while; the duke will drink under this tree. He hath been all this day to look you.

lines.speaker: jaques
lines.text: And I have been all this day to avoid him. He is too disputable for my company: I think of as many matters as he, but I give heaven thanks and make no boast of them. Come, warble, come. SONG. Who doth ambition shun And loves to live i' the sun, Seeking the food he eats And pleased with what he gets, Come hither, come hither, come hither: Here shall he see No enemy But winter and rough weather. I'll give you a verse to this note that I made yesterday in despite of my invention.
All together here

lines.speaker: amiens
lines.text: And I'll sing it.

lines.speaker: jaques
lines.text: Thus it goes:-- If it do come to pass That any man turn ass, Leaving his wealth and ease, A stubborn will to please, Ducdame, ducdame, ducdame: Here shall he see Gross fools as he, An if he will come to me.

lines.speaker: amiens
lines.text: What's that 'ducdame'?

lines.speaker: jaques
lines.text: 'Tis a Greek invocation, to call fools into a circle. I'll go sleep, if I can; if I cannot, I'll rail against all the first-born of Egypt.

lines.speaker: amiens
lines.text: And I'll go seek the duke: his banquet is prepared.
Exeunt severally
